Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. ANDREWS AIR FORCE BASE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Police cars, motorcycles and limousines arrive. Sirens are heard everywhere.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LIMOUSINE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Bartlet and Charlie are in one of the limos.

Dialogues.Line: He wants to meet with me on the way back?
The Assistant Energy Secretary is flying to Portland in the middle of the night so he can meet with me on Air Force One on the way back?
The day-to-day experience of my life has changed in many ways since taking this job.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. PRESS BUS - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: At the end of the motorcade, C.J. is sitting in front of the press bus, facing the many reporters who are accompanying Bartlet on the trip.

Dialogues.Line: Before we get on the plane, let me give you a couple of additions to the passenger manifest. Gerald Wegland, the Assistant Energy Secretary, is now on the flight, as well as Mr. Latham, the head of The White House Military Office, or WHAMO, as we have apparently taken - over my strong objection - to calling it. [Reporters giggle.] Also, on this evening's trip are Deputy Communications Director Sam Seaborn and, well, me.
I thought you weren't going on the trip.
I am now going on the trip.
I'm not being punished, I'm going on the trip.
If the whole bus goes off the record, will you tell us why you're going on the trip?
[watches everyone carefully] I made fun of Notre Dame.
I usually get away with it!
You can't bring that stuff when they're playing Michigan.
Well, I'll have a lot of time to think about that on the midnight ride to Portland, Danny. The wheels-up is 905. We'll touch down in Portland a little before midnight local time.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. ANDREWS AIR FORCE BASE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo approaches Bartlet's limo. Engines roar nearby.

Dialogues.Line: I just got off with Bruno and Hess.
I said I just got off with Bruno and Hess.
No, sir. We're standing pretty close to the engines so it may have sounded like I said, 'Notre Dame is gonna get the ass-kicking they so richly deserve.' Bruno and Hess?
We stopped the tanker in the Gulf.
It's Cyprus-flagged but they tracked them coming out of Qais.
Have a good flight, Mr. President.
Thank you! C.J. approaches from the side, Leo waves to her and leaves.
I think it's great you decided to make the trip.
I believe I was ordered to, Mr. President.
Yes. I remember now. You made one of your funny, funny jokes.
Sir, I'm wearing Max Mara. It's going to break up the...
Put it on! C.J. puts on the Notre Dame cap and grins at the officer in front of the plane door.
Please let nobody see me like this.
Oh good god. They turn to the people below the plane and wave. Bartlet - enthusiastically,

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - NIGHT
CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Josh is sitting at his desk.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LIMOUSINE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Leo is sitting inside. He is on the phone in the car.

Dialogues.Line: You told him about the tanker?
Yeah. I wish he'd cancel the event, it's a long flight.
He likes long flights, he gets to talk to everybody and think out loud.
Yeah, so... well, then he lands. [beat] Anyway, I'm going to meet with Matt Skinner.
He's gonna say the language in the bill doesn't prohibit.

Yeah, but it creates a Federal Definition. During this conversation, Donna, wearing a stunning red dress, comes in, turns off Josh's PC and laptop, picks up his feet to collect papers from his desk and flicks off the table lamp.
Yeah. Are you sticking around tonight?
The President's going to have to make a decision from the plane.
Okay. I have to go. Donna is about to cease the phone.
Leo. He likes long plane rides.
Yeah. Josh hangs up the phone.
Can I have the electricity back on?
No. She walks out of the office to JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA. Josh follows.
Not for me. Matt Skinner's coming down from the Hill.
[turns to Josh] When did this happen?
Two minutes ago. Did you have plans?
Yes, I do! She walks away. Josh follows again.
You weren't wearing that during the day today.
Pity the girl who tries to get something past you, Josh.
[puts on her coat] I'm a girl on a budget, Josh. I'm being thrifty.
And felonious. What are your plans?
We're having drinks, we're having dinner, we are going dancing, we are having dessert.
No problem. You can do all those things except for the drinks, the dancing, and the dessert.
I need you to be done with dinner in an hour and five minutes.
[shows him her dress again] Do you see what I'm wearing?
If you wanna have sex, you'd better do it during dinner.
[walks closer to him] This is the guy, Josh. This is a great guy. His name is Todd.
[smiling goofily] You met him for five minutes at a party.
I have an excellent sense about these things!

[turns back, yelling] Actually, you have NO sense about these things! You have no vibe, you have terrible taste in men, and your desire to be coupled up will always and forever drown out any small sense of self or self-worth that you may have.
[as her smile fades and about to cry] You're a downer, you know that? I'm calling you Deputy Downer from now on! She leaves the bullpen. Josh watches her go. Then walks to his office.
Be back by the time I'm done with Skinner!

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AIR FORCE ONE, STAFF CABIN - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam is sitting in a chair, looking nowhere. He's holding his speech carelessly in his hand.

Dialogues.Line: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen from the flight deck. We're just passing through 20,000 feet en route to our cruising altitude of 38,000 feet. Our flight plan this evening will take us over Pittsburgh and Cleveland, passing 190 miles south of the University of Notre Dame, then over Radic City, South Dakota; Casper, Wyoming, to... During the announcement, Sam jumps suddenly, and walks into a CABIN where Toby is sitting in an armchair.
Could I talk to you a second?
It... it's not... it's not good. It's not going well.
I'm not writing well. I'm just... I'd rather not distribute this to the pool yet. The steward walks into the cabin.
Mr. Ziegler, Mr. Seaborn, do you know what you'd like for dinner?
[gets up] We'll be eating in the conference room. I'll have a club sandwich, Jack Daniels and ice.
[to the steward] Bring him a club sandwich.
Yes, sir. They walk out of the room. C.J. is coming down the stairs to meet them.
[beat] Sam and I are going to work for a little bit, you'll have draft copies to distribute to the press in about three hours.
You have to get it back!
I'm doing more than polishing it, C.J., you've got to get it back!
I'll tell them there's a new draft and then you should...
You've got to get the old draft back!
They're not going to read it!
It's very bad writing and it's got my fingerprints all over it!
C.J., try to get it back. [walks past them, to Sam] C'mon.
Ms. Cregg, do you know what you'd like for dinner?
[pops up on extreme right, whispers] Try to get it back?
Ms. Cregg, you know what you'd like for dinner?
I'll take it. Bartlet and Charlie approach C.J.
What does the island of Qais mean to you?
[rolls her eyes, walks by him] I know it's known as a rendezvous point for Iraqi oil smugglers.
About two hours ago we stopped a Cyprus-flagged ship called "The Nicosia." We believe it to be carrying petroleum products out of Iraq, in violation of UN sanctions.
What do we do when that happens?
We board the stip, we test a sample of the oil, we determine its point of origin and if it's black-market, the oil company gets fined.
Don't they also get to sell the oil?
Doesn't the profit of the sale exceed the fine?
It dramatically exceeds the fine! So what do you think we should do?
If you're going to have sanctions, have sanctions. There should be genuine disincentive.
[hands C.J. some papers] Here you go.
The lyrics to the Notre Dame fight song.
It would please me if you would lead the press in a rendition as we pass over South Bend.
You bet your ass! Bartlet and Charlie walk away as C.J. stands still with her fist still clutched.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WHITE HOUSE MESS - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Ainsley, with a fan in her hand, walks into the cafeteria.

Dialogues.Line: Yes, could I have a chocolate chip muffin, a can of Fresca and a bag of ice, please?
I just went and got it from my apartment. [picks up food and they walk to exit]
Then I should move my desk outside, because it's a hundred and three in my office.
No, the heat's working great, I can vouch for that personally.
Okay. They walk in different directions.
You should really have Fresca in the building!

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Congressman Matt Skinner knocks on his office door. He is a short, neatly-dressed good looking man in his thirties.

Dialogues.Line: You let Donna out? [They shake hands.]
I guy she has no future with.
Because I say so. You want some coffee or something?
Yeah. [gets two bottles from the refrigerator] It's too bad this is going to be rushed.
It's too bad we're talking about this for the first time right now.
I would have thought that was by design.
We know you know. [Josh and Skinner sit down.] Josh, the language doesn't prohibit same-sex marriage.
It ensures that, for the purposes of Federal programs...
That government will define marriage as a union between a man and a woman.
That's right, while doing nothing to prohibit gay marriage on a state level.
While doing nothing to prohibit it?
If you look at the language...
When this bill was being discussed on the floor, there were some very ugly things said about homosexuals.
They were said by members of your own party. In fact, they were said by one of the guys who escorted you here tonight, who's sitting out in the lobby.
Yes, I am. They look at each other, and Skinner smiles.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE SITUATION ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo enters as a Navy officer MARK CHASE is waiting for him.

Dialogues.Line: The Sudanese captain of the tanker refused to let the Navy personnel on board.
47 Seahawk helicopter was dispatched from the destroyer 'USS Monterey.' The copter tried to land, but seamen obstructed the deck with freight.
What else did they obstruct the deck with?
Yes, at which point the Seahawk retreated to its carrier group.
Central Command's going to have two F-18s buzz the ship, fire warning shots over the bow.
There's no way this ends well. In fact, its' already over.
Trust me. I'll call the President. [walks out]

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Margaret enters Leo's office, stands by his desk, and looks at him.

Dialogues.Line: Can I just say that all I meant before was that if I was married and got divorced and my divorce papers came and I was an alcoholic, I would want to be...
[gives her a glare, picking up phone quickly] Yes, sir?
What are we trying to do?
We're trying to seize the ship and escort it to Bahrain.
They fire warning shots, maybe take out the propeller...
Leo, just so they know--it's a tanker full of crude oil. If they miss the propeller and hit something else---
They know. Excuse me, Mr. President. [whispering to Margaret] Would you stop looking at me like that? Margaret turns and leaves quickly.
Margaret was giving me a look.
My divorce papers came today. She thinks I'm going to drink

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AIR FORCE ONE, THE PRESIDENT'S CABIN - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is in his cabin, talking on the phone.

Dialogues.Line: Don't worry about it, Mr. President. I'll keep you posted.
Okay. Why don't I have a final draft of tomorrow morning's...?
Toby and Sam are working on it.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AIR FORCE ONE, STAFF CABIN - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam and are Toby working on the speech.

Dialogues.Line: [reading] 'I'm calling on all Americans, young and old, Democrat and Republican, or none of the above, to make education a national priority.'
[sighing] "None of the above." It's a pedestrian phrase and has no place. [crosses it out]
Also when was education not a national priority before?
Right. [clearing throat] It's an easy fix. All we need to do is...
No, it's not an easy fix.

Oratory should raise your heart rate. Oratory should blow the doors off the place. We should be talking about not being satisfied with past solutions, we should be talking about a permanent revolution.
[pausing and thinking] Where have I heard that?
[darkly] I got it from a book.
You think we should quote Mao Tse-tung?
We do need a permanent revolution.
Still, I think we'll stay away from quoting Communists.
You think a Communist never wrote an elegant phrase?
How do you think they got every to be Communist?
Toby, you're the one for the last six months who's been saying we need a radical approach...

[raising his voice] Yes, yes I have, and I got shouted down in every meeting! I'd love to write a speech about a radical new approach to education, but we don't have one! So unless we can come up with an idea and implement it before land in Portland, I'd prefer not to paint a picture in the interest of great oratory. [sighs] Let's take a walk.
Can't great oratory inspire an idea that can be implemented?
We had six months. We're not doing it half-assed, we're not doing it tonight. Let's go.
Up and down the plane, get the blood flowing.
Mao knew how to get the blood flowing.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE WHITE HOUSE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Donna enters the West Wing. Leo joins her, walking.

Dialogues.Line: You weren't wearing that dress earlier today, were you?
You guys are sharp as tacks, you know that?

Ah, good. You know what you get there? Tell Dario, the chef, that you work for me and that you want flash-seared escolar with foie gras butter and a fresh juniper berry gravlax on a bed of shaved fennel. You have a nice '87 Petrus with that. [beat] What did you have?
Two whiskey sours and a bowl of soup.
I should tell Josh I'm back.
Thanks. Hey, Leo. I hope you don't mind. [clears throat] Margaret mentioned that your divorce...
She mentioned the papers came today...
And she was worried that maybe...
Margaret worries if the sun is gonna rise. Go check in with Josh.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. WHITE HOUSE MESS - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh and Matt are in the mess, talking over a few beers.

Dialogues.Line: With 85 votes. 29 Democrats voted for it. It passed the House with 342 votes. Our polling numbers are the same as yours. 60% of Americans oppose legally sanctioned gay marriage. The people want the bill. Congress wants the bill. The President needs to sign the bill.
Public opinion can be wrong, Matt. The public opposed interracial marriage and school integration. You want me to reach back into the nostalgia file?
The government has a responsibility to protect the rights of minorities, but it can't impose the minority's values on the majority.
Freedom of choice isn't a minority value just because the majority doesn't agree with the minority's choice.
Uh, it was good. Josh, I'll be around.
Thanks. Donna exits, Matt and Josh watch her leave.
Josh, all the Marriage Recognition Act does is ensure that a radical social agenda isn't thrust upon an entire country that isn't ready for it yet.
32 States have passed laws banning same-sex marriage. The States are doing a fine job protecting themselves from a radical social agenda without a federal shield.
I like you guys who want to reduce the size of government and make it just small enough so it can fit in our bedrooms!
When do you have to call the President?
[glancing at his watch] I got time.
[loosening his tie] Let's have another beer.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AIR FORCE ONE, PRESS AREA - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J. taps Carol on the shoulder, adjusts her Notre Dame cap, and enters the press seating.

Dialogues.Line: C.J., why'd the flight take off so late?
No, I mean why was it scheduled late? I'm doing a side-bar.

I'm not sure. The President had a budget meeting earlier, maybe they were expecting it to run long, I'll find out. Listen, I'd like you to give me back the draft copies of the morning education speech. We're going to replace them.
Toby and Sam are doing some work.
Well, C.J., if there's a policy shift or a new program, it'd help to have the old text to compare it with...
There isn't a policy shift, there isn't a new program, this is Sam being Sam. Charlie enters and gets C.J.'s attention.
Has political pressure from the NEA forced changes in the...
Nothing's forced changes in the speech, there are no policy shifts and no new initiatives, I guarantee you. Carol?
Guys, they're in your press packets, if you could just hand them forward...
He wanted me to tell you that we're approaching South Bend and that he likes to hear the song at a brisk and steady tempo.
[staring at Charlie] Oh, kill me now!

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Margaret enters. Leo is reading.

Dialogues.Line: [motions her to wait a second] Yeah?
[as Mark enters] Mark, tell me we didn't hit anything.
No, F-18s fired over the bow and the tanker stopped.
Yeah, but the crew threw the log and the registry overboard.
How do these people think this is going to end? What is their best-case scenario?
I just go where you point me. I'm going to have to brief Fitzwallace now.
Can you get me Secretaries Hutchinson and Berryhill?
And I need Air Force One the next free minute he's got, okay?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AIR FORCE ONE, THE PRESIDENT'S CABIN - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The President is with two advisors, Steve Adamley and Mike.

Dialogues.Line: That's usually pretty hard to get through Congress.
Once you get south of DC or west of Chicago, there aren't any subways, and the ones they've got, nobody's using.
What about Miami and San Francisco? Someone knocks.
L.A., Miami, San Francisco, maybe someday, but nobody's using them now. C.J. enters. Mike stares at her hat. She stares back. He smiles just a little.
So pavement's going to win this battle?
Okay, thanks, Steve. They all rise as the advisors exit.
[putting on jacket] Ernesto Perez Balladares, former President of Panama. You know where he went to school? Notre Dame.
No, sir. I understand you'd like to hear the song now?

[as he and C.J. walk out] Yeah, but we gotta do it later. The Tokyo Exchange just opened and I'm gonna gauge the impact on Pacific Rim Banking Reforms. A subject economics scholars could take years on, I will take 20 minutes.
Speaking of which, Mr. President, I was asked about the late departure tonight.
I thought we left on time.
No, I was just repeating- Bartlet and C.J. enter another cabin. Sam and Toby are seated.

A long flight across the night? You know why late flights are good? Because we cease to be earthbound and burdened with practicality. Ask the impertinent question. Talk about the idea nobody has thought about yet. [pointing to Sam] Put it a different way.
He doesn't want to use the phrase "permanent revolution."
Mao took a lot of long plane flights, Toby. Look out your window. Is there anything more romantic than that? [pointing out cabin window]
And that's why we left at 905?
No, we left at 905 because they thought my budget meeting might run over. But wouldn't that have been great if that was the reason?
[to Toby] You don't like "permanent revolution"? A phone rings in background.
It's a nifty phrase, but I think if we call for a permanent revolution, people are, you know, gonna expect one.
We're flying, Toby. Live a little. [standing and walking to Charlie] Yeah?
Oh, Leo, just take the damn boat...

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. AINSLEY'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Ainsley is sitting at her desk with a fan blowing. Someone knocks on the door.

Dialogues.Line: I cant't turn the heat down.
No. I just looked at the thermostat and got frustrated.
Of course, I tried! I could grow papayas in here.
It's the steam pipe distribution venue.
Wanna come work upstairs in the bullpen?
Okay. I just came down to say hi.
And I'd talk but I just... I need to get this done.
[pauses] Do you and I look alike?
That's what I thought. I didn't think we looked alike.
Have you ever thought about dying your hair red?
No, and I tell people that. [pause] I'm going to work upstairs. [stands]
I think it's because of the alabaster skin and the farm girl looks that...
Yes. Are you sure you don't want to work upstairs?
No. It may be hot down here but at least it's quiet. The pipes make a loud banging sound, startling Ainsley.
Okay. She shuts her computer notebook and stands.
Boy, I could use a Fresca.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh and Skinner are talking.

Dialogues.Line: You're going to quote the bible to me?
My point was hat the founders based the country on Judeo-Christian morality...
...and that the biblical concept of marriage maybe can't be separated from the law quite as easily as you'd like.
The founding fathers made it very clear that they didn't want Judeo-Christian morality within 10 city blocks of the law. Matt! [pause]
What? Josh pauses, looking at Skinner.
Nothing. [sits] You understand that gay partners will be permanently ineligable for survivor benefits, Medicare, Medicaid....
Which the government can't afford to pay anyway.
So we caught a break there. [sighs]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AIR FORCE ONE, HALLWAY - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J. is walking down the hallway.

Dialogues.Line: Did you get the old drafts back?
Yeah. C.J. nods and turns to walk back down the hall.
Excuse me. She storms past Carol into the reporters' area and stands in front of Danny.
[looks up at her from his seat] How ya doing?

C.J., there's no earthly reason why I should give you that draft back and you know it. You can't even believe you're asking me for it. So unless you're going to give me a hot towel and some chocolate chip cookies, you better...
Everybody else gave it back, Danny.
Then everybody else can read my paper tomorrow.
[looks up and addresses all the reporters] I'm guaranteeing you all no substantive changes, no new policy initiatives.
You don't have to guarantee me anything. I've got the old draft right here.
[leans over and stage whispers to Danny] I certainly hope we don't accidentally send your luggage to Belgium on the way back. [walks away]
[raising his voice] Yeah, I wouldn't want to find out what it's like to be inconvenianced by the White House! C.J. stops at the doorway and turns to speak to a reporter in the front.
It was the budget meeting, by the way.
The reason we took off late. It was the budget meeting. Although there's something to be said for... [pause] something to be said for...
Something to be said for what?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AIR FORCE ONE, STAFF CABIN - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: In the staff cabin, Toby, Bartlet, and Sam are working on the education speech. Charlie is sitting in a chair writing.

Dialogues.Line: [reading from speech] "I was raised to appreciate the value of teachers and teaching. My grandmother, who began her teaching career in a one-room schoolhouse..."
Italian stonecutters were paying her to teach their kids English in the basement of the rectory. They put up a wall and made it two rooms as a thank you gift.
We'll change it to two rooms.
I haven't heard the big idea yet.
Sir, the speech is in pretty good shape.
Yeah. [reads from speech] "As you know, I began my campaign...'' [looks at Toby] What happened to 100,000 new teachers?
There aren't a 100,000 new teachers. We can't make people be teachers.
In certain public districts there are tax incentives...
Well, it's not doing the trick.
No. No. I know. But for right now...
[looking at what Charlie is writing] What's that mean?
You wrote down, "Send them to college."
What did you mean when you wrote down, "send them to college"?
No, 'cause it's like circling horses in the paper but not making the bet.
[stands and walks toward Charlie] Tuition incentives.
Mr. President, if this was an idea, somebody would have had it already.
I find fault with that formula.
The government will send you to college or law school or medical school if you spend three years in the armed forces. Why not...
[pacing] College tuition to anyone who wants to go college in exchange for they teach in a public school where we send'em for three years.
Why can't that idea be floated?
Anybody know how we pay for it?
Yes, it does come next, so for the moment why don't we...
[walks to the door] I'll be in my study. It's an incredible sky tonight.
Ladies and gentleman, this is Colonel Beach from the flight deck. We've been told there's choppy wind ahead and we've been cleared to climb to 42,000 feet.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: I know what 57% of the people say.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Josh and Skinner are walking down the hallway.

Dialogues.Line: 58% of the people say that gay spouses should receive health benefits and 54% say Social Security benefits and by the way we haven't talked about the 14th amendment.
I think a strict interpretation of the Equal Protection Clause would dictate that homophobia can't be made into a law.
That's for the court to decide; but I think they'll uphold it. They enter JOSH'S OFFICE. Josh stands behind his desk facing Skinner.
Lawrence Tribe doesn't sit on the U.S. Supreme Court.
Josh, I came here as a friend. I think you know that.
What does that have to do with it?
I came here 'cause I came here. Look. This is gonna be a law whether the President vetoes it or not. They have the votes in the Senate to override it.
The Senate's not in session. The President could stick this in his pants pocket and it's vetoed.
And it will come back in January and you will have to live through this twice. And you will lose both times.
He compared homosexuality to kleptomania and sex addition, Matt.
The Majority Leader. The leader of your own party.
He was wrong and I told him so.
How can you be a member of this party?!?
You've been holding that in for way too long, man.
This party who says that who you are is against the law.

You know, I never understand why you gun control people don't all join the N.R.A. They've got two million members. You bring three million to the next meeting... call a vote... All those in favor of tossing guns - [Snaps fingers] - Bam! Move on.
That's a heck of a strategy, Matt. I'll bring that up in a meeting. Josh sighs heavily as he collapses into his chair.

I agree with 95% of the Republican platform. I believe in local government. I'm in favor of individual rights rather than group rights. I believe free markets lead to free people and that the country needs a strong national defense. My life doesn't have to be about being a homosexual. It doesn't have to be entirely about that. Josh looks at Skinner thoughtfully before deciding not to continue.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. NORTHWEST LOBBY - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Two men are waiting on Skinner. One sits while the other paces. Skinner walks up.

Dialogues.Line: Oh... there he is. [to Skinner] How'd it go?
He'll sign it. Josh observes the congressmen from his doorway.
Ooo hoo! I can tell McDougal?
[puts on his coat] Yeah. As they head for the exit, one of them claps Skinner's shoulder. His hand lingers there.
Take your hand off my shoulder, Congressman. The camera lingers on a conflicted Josh watching the exiting congressmen.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AIR FORCE ONE, STAFF CABIN - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: JET ROUTE 60 CASPER, WYOMING Toby sits behind a desk and Sam paces in front of the desk.
Toby... C.J. opens the office door which cuts Toby and Sam short.
You should tip the press off we might float an education initiative.
We might float, I'm sayin' and you should give them a heads up.
Excuse me. I need to go look like an idiot. C.J. leaves closing the office door behind her.
We're not floating a policy initiative, Sam. I don't care if it's a trip to the moon on gossamer wings.
It's pie in the sky to say nothing of patronizing to have privileged Ivy Leaguers play teacher to America's most vulnerable children.
The people taking advantage of this aren't going to be over-privileged.
How do you suppose the teacher's union will feel about it?
All of whom will leave after three years.
And the kids will be abandoned as well.
Once you're in fifth grade what do you care what your fourth grade teacher is doing?
Toby, these people are gonna be role models, to kids that don't have much contact with young, successful, college graduates many of whom will have grown up in neighborhoods just like theirs.
Sam! Where are we getting the money? [pauses to reign in his temper] Where are we getting the money?
I was really mortified that I froze up on that speech.
Yeah. [pause] You should've told me a few days ago.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Ainsley sits at a desk typing and Donna sits on the desk talking.

Dialogues.Line: I played the flute. I'm a flutist. In high school I was the best in my row. And, so I ask myself, if I pursued the flute professionally, would I be meeting interesting men? And the answer comes back to me. Probably not.
Is, is it a hard instrument to learn? If I took it up now... Josh walks up and interrupts Donna who hops up off the desk and exits.
Talk to me about the Full Faith and Credit Clause.

It says that full faith and credit shall be given by each state to the public acts, records, and judicial proceedings of every other state - it means if you're married in Maryland it's got to be recognized by Nebraska.
So, how is the Marriage Recognition Act not unconstitutional?

'Cause it also says that Congress can proscribe the manner in which such acts and records are proved - which means they can decide what being married means within the context of Article IV. Donna is behind the glass partition in the bullpen and has answered a phone.
[pointing to phone sitting in cradle] Toby. Josh walks around the glass partition and picks up the phone.
I'm going to tell him to sign the damn thing.
You know when he goes off on a thing Toby, he expects you to bring him in. He wants you to do it so he doesn't have to do it himself.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AIR FORCE ONE, STAFF CABIN - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: Josh, off the top of your head, what do you think about tuition incentives for... Toby stops mid-question as he hears an announcement on the PA begin.
Ladies and gentlemen, from the flight deck. We're 82 miles south of the runway and beginning our descent. We'd like to ask you all to find a seat. Thank you.
No, I mean, what were you going to...
All right. I'll talk to you later. Josh and Donna begin making their way out of the bullpen past Ainsley. Josh walks a pace in front of Donna.
Take it easy. Josh and Donna continue walking down the HALLWAY.
Did you know she plays the trombone?
I didn't mean having to work, although that was a treat. I meant the guy.
A lobbyist with Travis West. He was pretty full of himself and without a lot of cause to be.
An obnoxious insurance lobbyist? What were the odds?
I gotta go see Leo. Josh turns and continues walking down the hallway as Donna veers off to start heading for the exit.
I'll call you in the morning. Josh stops walking and turns back towards Donna.

You look really great in that dress tonight, Donna. You should buy it for yourself. Josh smiles at Donna and again turns to walk towards Leo's office. Donna smiles as she watches Josh walk away before exiting herself.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo sits on his couch with a phone sitting next to him.

Dialogues.Line: [on speakerphone] Yeah? Leo doesn't answer immediately. Bartlet repeats himself less patiently.
We hold the ship in Bahrain.
It doesn't do anything to hold the ship in Bahrain
Sir, we hold the ship in Bahrain and then send a sample of the oil to the U.S. customs lab in San Francisco. If the point of origin violates sanctions...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AIR FORCE ONE, THE PRESIDENT'S CABIN - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: 3 LANDING ROUTE PORTLAND, OREGON Bartlet is standing talking on the phone.
Yeah. You know what's going to happen? They'll sell off the cargo in a friendly port. 780,000 metric tons of gas oil against a two million dollar fine for the oil company.
Which their profits from the sale will more than cover. We're not providing much of a disincentive to evade U.N. sanctions. Josh enters LEO'S OFFICE and takes a seat in the chair near Leo.
What else is there to do?

If we're going to have sanctions at all, I think we should make them stick. I think that we should confiscate the cargo, seize the ship, sell the oil and use the money to beef up anti-smuggling operations.
You don't mean tonight. You mean in the future... Bartlet sighs heavily in resignation. C.J. enters the room.
Okay. Josh wants to talk about the...
[to Leo] Hang on. [to C.J.] You need me?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AIR FORCE ONE, PRESS AREA - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J. approaches the front of the Press Area facing the reporters. As C.J. begins to speak, Toby approaches and stands near C.J..

Dialogues.Line: Folks, we'll be landing in just a few minutes. Follow the blue signs to your bus. Oh, one thing before we land, when I said before that there'd be absolutely no policy shifts or new initiatives in the education speech tomorrow... That was correct, except it's possible there might be a policy shift or new initiative in the education speech tomorrow. The reporters groan and grumble.
There isn't going to be a change.
There isn't going to be a change! [to C.J.] Danny?
He's not going to give it back. Toby heaves a sigh and walk over to Danny then sits in the seat beside him.
Danny, Sam choked hard on the last draft and wants to burn it. Danny pauses a couple of seconds to think it over.
[to Toby] Tell him to relax. He'll get his swing back.
Yeah. Toby stands and begins to walk away.
Tell him I didn't read it.
[smiling slightly] Thanks. Toby exits with the draft in hand.
You were just having a little go at me, weren't you?
So you decided to kill time by...
Tell me you went to Notre Dame.
Maybe next time you won't be so quick to mock on the eve of a Michigan game. C.J. frowns at Danny a moment before turning and walking towards the front of the plane away from the Press Area.
[to herself] There must be an escape hatch here of some kind.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh continues his conversation with Bartlet. Leo paces the office listening.

Dialogues.Line: I don't care about the constitutional argument. It's gay bashing. It's legislative gay bashing. How do I put my name on it?
I wouldn't, sir. I'd put it away.
Pocket veto's a politician's way out.
They'll send the bill again when they're in session. Meanwhile, we focus on the Employment Non-discrimination Act.
If I'm going to sign it in January, why am I vetoing it now?
As a symbolic gesture to the gay community.
I'm sure the gay community can't wait to thank me.

[getting worked up] You can look at the policy numbers and Article IV and Social Security benefits. It doesn't matter. It's just wrong. We shouldn't be defining love and we certainly shouldn't be ill-defining it. It's wrong. This is the job for... This is the job of somebody else.
I should get out a rubber stamp that says 'Josiah Bartlet votes no.'
That's just what the conservatives are hoping you'll do.
I should get out a rubber stamp! Bartlet heaves an exasperated sigh.
We'll talk at the hotel. [hangs up] Leo and Josh sit quietly a second.
My divorce papers came today. She thinks I'm going to drink.
It seems like a pretty good reason to.
I'm an alcoholic, I don't need a good reason to.
I'll see you on Monday. Josh exits. Leo grabs his coat and scarf and starts putting them on.
[calls] Margaret, I'm going. Margaret stops what she's doing and walks into Leo's office.
[with a resigned tone, yet worried expression] Okay. Leo looks at Margaret for a moment.
[quietly] You're a good girl. Leo turns and leaves, closing his office door behind him as Margaret watches.
[pacified] Okay. Margaret closes the door between her office and Leo's as she steps back into her own office are

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AIR FORCE ONE, THE PRESIDENT'S CABIN - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is sitting in a chair reading something as C.J. enters.

Dialogues.Line: Yeah. C.J. crosses room and sits on bench next to Bartlet.
For a sidebar, on the game tomorrow. She indicates the hat to show she means the Notre Dame game.
Why did you go to Notre Dame?
Bearing in mind that I'm just repeating someone else's question. You were accepted at Harvard, Yale, and Williams. Why did you go to Notre Dame?
Because I was thinking about becoming a priest.
[obviously touched] Why don't you ever give me answers like that when we're running for something?
Because I like to bother you.
Well, I shall not be defeated.
Okay. [sits] Toby enters the office carrying a folder. He extracts some pages and hands them to Bartlet.
Toby, you should sit down. We're landing in one minute and ten seconds.
I set my watch to the cockpit computer. You should sit down.
Do you know why the Assistant Energy Secretary is on the plane?
You have a meeting with him on the way back.
I think Charlie's idea was a good one. I think you should ask Leo to put together a team to study the feasibility of appropriations for a pilot program with 100 teachers.
They're taking the tanker to Bahrain and then the company's going to make a profit.
The Marriage Recognition Act is going to be law. In the background we hear the landing gear go down...
Well, it's a start I guess. We hear the screech of the airplane's wheels touching down.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
